conclusion: Average velocity is given by the area under the velocity-time graph divided by the time interval.
Car A's velocity increases over time. Car B's velocity decreases over time.
The average velocity for Car A can be approximated by the area under the curve for Car A from t=0 to t=t1.
The average velocity for Car B can be approximated by the area under the curve for Car B from t=0 to t=t1.
The area under the curve for Car A appears to be larger than the area under the curve for Car B because the curve for Car A is above the curve for Car B throughout the entire time interval.
Since the area under the curve for Car A is greater than the area under the curve for Car B, the average velocity of Car A is greater than the average velocity of Car B.
